serviceProviders.name: Barnabus
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Hot drinks, toast and cereals are all free in our Beacon centre 5 days a week. Hot food is on offer for a fee of 50p. This includes a fully cooked breakfast and as much tea and coffee as our friends would like. Hot food, biscuits and brews are also available in our afternoon drop-in sessions. The Beacon is also open on a Tuesday evening 7.45 to 9pm serving a hot meal and drinks.

serviceProviders.name: Coffee4Craig
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Street Kitchen based on the street outside Manchester Cathedral. Offering hot food, support and advice to anyone experiencing homelessness, at risk of becoming homeless and those in food poverty.&#10;&#10;We also offer signposting to other agencies during this time.

serviceProviders.name: Booth Centre
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Free breakfast. Advice is available at all sessions.

serviceProviders.name: Booth Centre
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Lunch

serviceProviders.name: Cornerstone
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Tea and coffee is served throughout the day. Breakfast: toast, porridge and cereal. Sandwiches. Lunch: soup and bread, a hot meal, dessert.
tags: Adults facing a wide range of social issues including homelessness.

serviceProviders.name: Salford Loaves and Fishes
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Cheap hot meals, showers and laundry. Free tea, coffee and soup.

serviceProviders.name: Mad Dogs Street Project
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Hotpots, stews, cakes and flapjack delivered directly.

serviceProviders.name: Justlife
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: A free, nutritious, hot meal is provided on a Monday and hot pasties are served on a Friday.
tags: People living in unsupported temporary accommodation (B&B's)

serviceProviders.name: The Wellspring
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Free food and drink is available 365 days a year.

serviceProviders.name: The Wellspring
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Free food and drink is available 365 days a year.

serviceProviders.name: Greystones Housing Group
serviceProviders.serviceInfo:
The IMPACT Project is adjacent to the Greystones supported housing unit. 

The project provides a day support service where people who are sleeping rough are provided light meals.

When receiving a notification that someone is sleeping rough in Tameside we also provide an outreach service where we make contact with the person on the street and endeavour to put them in contact with the services they need.
tags: 18+ and either rough sleeping or are at a severe risk of doing so

serviceProviders.name: Urban Outreach Bolton
serviceProviders.serviceInfo:
WINTER WATCH AND STOREHOUSE FOOD BANK

Winter Watch is our winter café providing food and warmth for the homeless and isolated. Last year over 400 individuals accessed the service; Storehouse food bank distributed 4,534 food parcels, supporting 1,391 adults and 812 children.

STOREHOUSE PANTRY

Using surplus food from FareShare, local food sources and bulk buying Storehouse Pantry provides everyday goods to pantry members at a low cost, accessed from a local church building on Johnson Fold.

LOCAL WELFARE PROVISION, CHRISTMAS DINNER ON JESUS AND BL LUNCHES

Local Welfare Provision (crisis food) issues over 1,800 parcels, supporting 2300 adults and nearly 1000 children each year. We also provide 1200 Christmas hampers and 1,300 packed lunches a day during the school summer holidays.

FRIENDS OF FUN FOOD

Friends of Fun Food is a project offering cooking and meal planning support to our clients and fun food sessions to schools and communities.

serviceProviders.name: St Ann's Church
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: The Morning Hours early hours drop in offers a basic breakfast of tea/coffee and toast each Friday.

serviceProviders.name: The vow team
serviceProviders.serviceInfo: Soup kitchen from 7-9pm every Friday at Cathedral Gardens.

serviceProviders.name: Mustard Tree
serviceProviders.serviceInfo:
Every Friday evening between 19:00 – 20:30, we invite guests into our Ancoats base where we serve them with a hot and nutritious meal. Typically we serve up to 90 people who live on the streets, in hostels, temporary accommodation or who are simply struggling to survive in their current situations.

From the Soup Run, we are able to signpost to Mustard Tree premises during the week to receive blankets and warm clothes, or to other organisations for advice and support.  Whilst the provision of food and drink is essential, the Soup Run also offers an opportunity to listen to and befriend those who attend.
